fields.template_text: Your BMI is {bmi}. Aim for a gradual 5–7% weight loss by adopting a balanced calorie-controlled diet and at least 150 minutes of moderate exercise per week.
Your fasting glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Reduce simple sugars—choose whole grains and high-fiber foods to help stabilize blood sugar.

Your blood glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Since elevated glucose can be better managed when you’re well-hydrated, aim for ≥8 cups (≈2 L) of water daily and limit sugary or caffeinated drinks.
At age {age}, regular cardio can improve insulin sensitivity. Start with 30 minutes of brisk walking or cycling, 5 days per week, to lower your diabetes risk.
With a BMI of {bmi}, adding resistance training twice weekly can build muscle and help control glucose—try bodyweight exercises or light weights.
Heart disease status = {heart_disease}. Flexibility exercises like yoga or stretching 3×/week improve mobility and reduce cardiovascular strain.
You reported '{smoking_history}' smoking. Quitting reduces diabetes complications—consider nicotine replacement or counseling programs for support.
Good sleep habits support insulin sensitivity. Aim for 7–9 hours nightly: keep a regular schedule and reduce screen time before bed.
Hypertension = {hypertension}. Chronic stress raises blood sugar; practice 5 minutes of deep breathing or mindfulness daily to help lower your risk.
Your BMI is {bmi}. Tracking meals helps identify high-calorie patterns and maintain portion control based on your BMI and glucose readings.
Your fasting glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Swap one refined starch per day (e.g., white bread) for a whole grain to reduce post-meal spikes.
At age {age}, prolonged sitting weakens glycemic control. Stand or walk for 5 minutes every hour to boost circulation and lower your diabetes risk.
Your blood glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Avoid heavy meals or caffeine within 3 hours of bedtime to promote restful sleep and stable overnight glucose.
Your HbA1c is {HbA1c_level} %. Brief walks in nature lower stress hormones and can help manage your glucose levels—try 10 minutes daily..
Your blood glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Starting each meal with a glass of water can curb appetite and support glucose balance.
